The new experiment that we have set up involves this piece of equipment

I find it quite remarkable that this cloud, which is up here, an oppressive dark structure,
is actually able to suck water out of the ocean. Quite how it manages to do that is, I think
we'd like to investigate. We've got a six km by 6 km per map of the surrounding area.
The radar is located in the middle here.
These returns here are from ground and nearby buildings.
When a shower comes by, what we see is this moving object here,
with the yellow areas being heavy rain and the bluer areas being lighter rain.
What the radar actually sees is the radar return from the raindrops itself, so we can
measure the amount of water that's in the cloud.
The last radar images we showed you was the shower that just went by.
A couple of weeks ago something much more exciting happened.
What you can see here is much more intense rainfall coming through.
These large red areas, not only a heavy rain,
but contained a significant number of hailstones. And this went on for some time. So this was
actually a flooding event with very heavy rain. You can see just at the moment there, very
heavy stuff going over the radar. When it had gone through and everybody thought it was over,
there's a long, thin cloud was left behind. And you can see at the top right hand side here.
If you look closely at the end here you can see a rotating cloud.
That rotating cloud is a good radar record of a tornado.
These are very hard to obtain.
If we had had the radar out in this muddy field for the next 200 years,
there's very little chance you'd have actually recorded a tornado and yet we got lucky.
And this shows how you need to be lucky as well as doing the right things to do science.
This is the photograph of the actual tornado that went past our facility here near Ardmore Airport,
south of Auckland.
From the radar image we can see how fast the cloud is rotating around the centre of rotation.
When you put the numbers in for the speed,
you discover there must be a very large force
constraining the cloud to go in a circle.
That force is provided by having a low pressure in the middle of the cloud.
What it means is that that tornado is acting like a large vacuum cleaner
and that vacuum cleaner is capable of picking up cows and cars
and even water out of the ocean.
So we now get numbers on what that low pressure is because we can see the detailed
rotation around the outside.
That was a pretty straightforward explanation of how tornadoes work, but we've still
got all these clouds out here not falling on the ground.
The man who did the original experiments to find out why that would be was a man called
Brown who was looking at pollen in water and he noticed the little pollen grains jiggled about. He initially thought that was because
they were alive in some sense but then he made suspensions of other little particles
in water and discovered they all jiggled around too even though they couldn't possibly be alive.
The theory of all that was sorted out by Albert Einstein who showed conclusively that the
reason that particles jiggered around is that they were being hit upon by the molecules of the water in the case of pollen or by air molecules in the
case of cloud water droplets.
So the reason the cloud stays up there is precisely because the air is jiggling the little
molecules around giving a much bigger force than the MG down.
Small particles then stay up in the sky forever until either they combine together and make
a raindrop when they really do fall out of the sky or they evaporate. So these clouds
can stay around a long time and the man who sort of that all out for us is Albert Einstein.
